lexUnit.name: bake.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: cook food by dry heat without direct exposure to a flame, typically in an oven

sentence.text: The bread would then be slipped in , the oven door sealed , and when the oven cooled , the bread would be baked .
It is also illegal in Norway for a bakery to bake bread on a Saturday or Sunday .
Almost all the food is grown at camp ; they bake their own bread and the food is not only 100% nutritious but very delicious .
Rosalind bakes her own bread and croissants and will prepare an evening meal with advance notice .
And she baked some bread with the millet flour that she had brought from her own garden .
Some larger stores sell special tins of all the numbers so you can bake a cake in the shape of your child 's age .
Believing in economy , Miss Lodsworth had already baked rock and fairy cakes and spread hundreds of sandwiches with crusts still on with Marmite and plum jam which was cheaper than strawberry .
And she would bake a chocolate mousse torte .
And for tomorrow 's Sunday dinner , she was going to roast a leg of mutton and bake an apple pie .
I baked some currant buns for you . "
The wife of Senator Arlen Specter even baked Ali a double chocolate-mousse pie .
Louise had baked a pie for him and was bringing a new pair of sheets from the airing cupboard .
In Spain , breads flavoured with cinnamon and dried fruit are baked at Easter , and some contain hard-boiled eggs , according to Elizabeth Luard 's European Festival Food .
A special birthday cake was baked to mark the occasion , which was held in Graham School .
A jubilee cake was baked , and the head girl Laura Berry and the head boy , Brian Quinn , presented the Bishop with a memento of the occasion .
